title: 108_s323
content:
The Act titled "Atchafalaya National Heritage Area Act" establishes the Atchafalaya National Heritage Area and defines key terms such as Heritage Area, local coordinating entity, management plan, Secretary, and State of Louisiana. The Atchafalaya National Heritage Area is established in Louisiana, encompassing several parishes. The local coordinating entity, the Atchafalaya Trace Commission, consists of 13 members appointed by each parish's governing authority. The local coordinating entity for the Atchafalaya National Heritage Area in Louisiana has the authority to make grants, hire staff, and enter contracts. Their duties include submitting a management plan for approval and implementing programs for resource recognition and economic development within the area. The local coordinating entity for the Atchafalaya National Heritage Area in Louisiana has the authority to establish interpretive sites, increase public awareness of resources, adopt bylaws, and submit annual reports. They are prohibited from using Federal funds to acquire real property. The local coordinating entity for the Atchafalaya National Heritage Area in Louisiana can establish interpretive sites, raise public awareness, adopt bylaws, and submit reports. They must hold public meetings quarterly. The management plan for the Atchafalaya National Heritage Area in Louisiana includes establishing interpretive sites, raising public awareness, adopting bylaws, submitting reports, and holding quarterly public meetings. The local coordinating entity develops a management plan for the Heritage Area, considering state and local plans and involving residents, agencies, and organizations. The plan includes an inventory of resources to be preserved and restored. The management plan for the Heritage Area includes provisions for protection, interpretation, and enjoyment of resources, an interpretation plan, and a program for implementation involving government, organizations, and partnerships. The local coordinating entity must submit the management plan for the Heritage Area to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of the Act's enactment. Failure to do so will result in a halt of additional funding. The Secretary, in consultation with the State, will approve or reject the plan within 90 days of submission. The Secretary, in consultation with the State, will approve or disapprove the management plan. If disapproved, the Secretary will provide reasons, make recommendations for revisions, and allow for resubmission within 90 days. After approval by the Secretary of a management plan, the local coordinating entity shall periodically review and submit recommendations for any revisions to the plan. No funds can be used to implement a revision until approved by the Secretary. The effect of the act is outlined in Section 6. The Heritage Area Act does not grant regulatory authority to any Federal agency over the area, does not change existing land use regulations, does not give zoning power to the local coordinating entity, does not impose new environmental standards, and does not alter Federal environmental quality standards. The Heritage Area Act does not authorize changes in federal environmental quality standards, water use designations, or permitting procedures within or adjacent to the Heritage Area. The Heritage Area Act does not authorize changes in federal environmental quality standards, water use designations, or permitting procedures within or adjacent to the Heritage Area. It affects the continuing use and operation of any public utility or common carrier. SEC. 7. REPORTS.

The local coordinating entity must submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing their accomplishments, expenses, and income.

SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

$10,000,000 is authorized for this Act, with a maximum of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. The Federal share of costs for any activity should not exceed 50%.

SEC. 9. TERMINATION OF AUTHORITY.

The Secretary's assistance to the local coordinating entity under this Act ends 15 years after enactment.

Passed the Senate on September 15, 2004. The Senate passed the Act on September 15, 2004. Attest: EMILY J. REYNOLDS, Secretary.
